title: alloc_system being pulled in by default even when a crate defines its own allocator
body:
We have a `#![no_std]` crate that defines its own allocator (i.e. using `#![allocator]`). This was working fine as of this nightly release, and releases prior to it:

```
rustc 1.18.0-nightly (d5cf1cb64 2017-04-15)
```

However, as of this release, `alloc_system` seems to be pulled in by default without us specifically requesting it:

```
rustc 1.18.0-nightly (7627e3d31 2017-04-16)
```

This results in the following errors during linking:

```
target/powerpc-unknown-linux-gnu/release/libchainenclave.a(alloc_system-68e33a366943aef4.0.o): In function `__rust_allocate':
alloc_system.cgu-0.rs:(.text.__rust_allocate+0x0): multiple definition of `__rust_allocate'
target/powerpc-unknown-linux-gnu/release/libchainenclave.a(chainenclave-bb03325c6a94dde4.0.o):chainenclave.cgu-0.rs:(.text.__rust_allocate+0x0): first defined here
/opt/nfast/gcc/bin/powerpc-codesafe-elf-ld: Warning: size of symbol `__rust_allocate' changed from 32 in target/powerpc-unknown-linux-gnu/release/libchainenclave.a(chainenclave-bb03325c6a94dde4.0.o) to 108 in target/powerpc-unknown-linux-gnu/release/libchainenclave.a(alloc_system-68e33a366943aef4.0.o)
```

Unfortunately alloc_system does not work at all in our environment:

```
alloc_system.cgu-0.rs:(.text.__rust_allocate_zeroed+0x50): undefined reference to `posix_memalign'
```

Is there any way to disable alloc_system and use our own allocator?

I should probably note we are using `libcollections` (now `liballoc`) for `Box`, `String`, and `Vec`. I'm wondering if that may be the cause.

I tried to find any suspect commits around this time. This is the only one I see touching the allocator code, and it doesn't jump out at me as an immediate culprit:

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/675475c4d3e3b1ebff5b761570f4a3f9a0ca23df
